titleStmt.title: A Transcription with commentary of Arboleda de los enfermos/ Grove of the Infirm by Teresa de Cartagena

sourceDesc.p: The original manuscript is from the National Library of the Escorial in Madrid, Spain

ab.note: the combination of the cloister reference with the idea of consulting books with "grafts" curiously incorporates different aspectst of convent life: the cloister, the library and the garden.
The juxtaposition of her admission to knowing how to read and interpret the voices in her books with the following line describing the inadequacy of her abilities cannot be mere circumstance.

¶Teresa describes the physical action of her approach to reading and interpreting. She models behaviour for her audience in a sort of metaperformative way Comȳenço a buscar en su devotisyma cançonero q·ue
Salterio se llama Psalm 23 (Siendo Ihovah mi pastor, de nada carecere; En amenos prador me hara reposar; a aguas apacibles me conducira; Recreara mi alma; conducirame por carriles de justicia en gracia de su nombre") is the most well known of this Psalter collection, however psalm 5 seems to speak more to Teresa's concerns: "Mis palabras escucha, Ihovah, entiende mi murmullo. Atiende a mi clamorosa voz, Rey mio y Señor mio, que a ti me dirijo. Ihovah, de mañana oiras mi voz; de mañana me presentare a ti y esperare..." algunas buenas consolaciones ⁊e falle maˢs

to in the margin there is a faint arrowTeresa uses the metaphor of food to refer to the consolations she enounters in the psalter. Seindenspinner-Nuñez suggests that Pedro de Luna also referred to God's counsel as food, (footnotes 24-25) no todos Cabrian dexare los que non dexan por eso de ser two squiggly lines

que mas hazen no solo al proposyto de mi pasyōn mas al aumēn
taçion de mi devoçion y cōn Solaçion espiritual notice how Teresa indicates her process of critical reading. She explains how, faced with a limited "plato" she must chose which psalms apply to her particular situation and serve her specific purposes. She is, therefore, not a passive reader, but rather an active participant in her own education. The skill she is relating demonstrates an essential one for the autodidact. And by extensions being an autodidact must have been an asset to her as a woman.

Salvaçion cunplⁱa hisome de la mano this is an interesting desctiption of the language of gestures or signs. It is remenicscient of the anecdote recounted in the introduction of the Libro de buen amor (el disputatio de las señas...).que callase ⁊e bien se
puede asy desir pues esta pasion es dad a mi por su mano this folio marks the beginning of Teresa's use of physical demonstration to express herself. Hands are important as are the signs they make. God's simple gesture of placing a finger to his lips decided Teresa's existence as a deaf person. For Teresa, God had to make teh signs twice (according to her) for her to become completely silent. Inadvertently, Teresa reveals some of what must have been her more headstrong nature. Ꝫ

El deseo que me solia haser no pequeño daño Teresa's use of examples to explain her more abstract concepts speaks directly to her intention to be clear and communicate a teachable message.
